Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: Assisting at a traffic accident scene to ensure safety and order
Story: I stared at my phone, the calendar notification for our weekly team meeting blinking at me. As a colleague, I was expected to join, share updates, and show my commitment to the team. Even though the meeting would be recorded, I knew my absence would be noticed, and I didn’t want to let my coworkers down. But just as I was about to log in, my police radio crackled to life—there’d been a traffic accident nearby, and officers were needed to secure the scene and help the injured. My heart pounded. As a police officer, my duty was clear: protect people, respond quickly, and keep order. I could almost hear my sergeant’s voice reminding me that every second counts in emergencies. Yet, I also felt the weight of my team’s expectations, the subtle disappointment if I missed another meeting. Torn between two worlds, I hesitated, feeling the pressure of both roles squeezing me from opposite sides, unsure which responsibility should come first.
